title: 2 Easy Ways to Move Photos to an SD Card on a Samsung

steps.title: Open the My Files app.
steps.content: Open the My Files app. This app comes preinstalled on all Samsung Galaxy devices, and the app icon has a yellow background with a folder on it. You can find it in your Apps menu in the Samsung folder. [1] X Research source Make sure you have an SD card inserted in your phone. Samsung Galaxy phones have SD card slots in different places depending on the version. Some can be found under the phone's back cover, while others have a slot at the top of the device. [2] X Research source The Samsung Galaxy S21, S21+, S21 Ultra, S6, Note 10, and Note 20 models do not support SD card storage.

steps.title: Tap Internal Storage.
steps.content: Tap Internal Storage . It's the first option below the categories box. This contains all files and folders on your phone.

steps.title: Navigate to the folder that contains the image you want to move.
steps.content: Navigate to the folder that contains the image you want to move. Images may be stored in a few different locations. Images taken with your camera are generally in the "DCIM" folder. Other images may be in the "Pictures" folder. Images associated with a particular app (i.e., Photoshop Express, Instagram) may be stored in a folder for that app inside the "Pictures" or "DCIM" folder.

steps.title: Long press on a photo.
steps.content: Long press on a photo. Pick a photo you want to move and hold your finger on it until your phone vibrates. You'll know the photo is selected by the yellow checkmark to the left of the image.

steps.title: Tap on any other photos you want to move.
steps.content: Tap on any other photos you want to move. Now that you are in selection mode, you can just tap on any other photos you wish to move. Once again, you'll know they're selected by the yellow checkmark. Alternatively, you can long-press an entire folder full of images to select the entire folder.

steps.title: Tap Move.
steps.content: Tap Move . It's at the bottom of the screen in the lower-left corner. It has an icon that resembles a folder with an arrow pointing right. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Navigate back to the main menu in My Files.
steps.content: Navigate back to the main menu in My Files. Tap the icon that resembles a bracket pointing left, either in the upper-left corner or at the bottom of the screen, to back out of each folder. Keep navigating back until you return to the Home menu of the My Files app.

steps.title: Tap SD card.
steps.content: Tap SD card . It's the second option below the "Categories" window. It will be right beneath the Internal storage option. Depending on the type of SD card or the Samsung Galaxy model, it might say Memory card instead.

steps.title: Choose a folder.
steps.content: Choose a folder. Scroll through the list of available folders and subfolders until you find the ideal location. Tap the folder to which you want to move the image(s). Alternatively, you can create a folder for these photos. To do so, tap the icon with three dots in the upper-right corner. Then tap Create Folder . Type a name for the folder and then tap Create . Then tap the folder you just created to open it.

steps.title: Tap Move Here.
steps.content: Tap Move Here . It's in the lower-right corner of the screen. This moves the folder you selected to the current location on the SD card. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Open the Gallery app.
steps.content: Open the Gallery app. It looks like an icon of a flower on a pinkish-red background. Make sure you open the Samsung version of Gallery instead of a third-party app like Google Photos. Make sure you have an SD card inserted in your phone. Samsung Galaxy phones have SD card slots in different places depending on the version. Some can be found under the phone's back cover, while others have a slot at the top of the device. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Tap Albums.
steps.content: Tap Albums . It's at the bottom of your screen.

steps.title: Tap +.
steps.content: Tap + . You'll see a plus sign at the top of your screen that gives you more options to create an album. If you don't see the plus sign, tap ⋮ > Create album .

steps.title: Tap Album.
steps.content: Tap Album . If you plan on taking pictures of specific people in the future and want to automatically save those captures to your SD card, select Auto-updating album instead. Skip this step if you chose Create album in the previous step.

steps.title: Tap Internal Storage.
steps.content: Tap Internal Storage . You won't see this option if you don't have an SD card inserted in your phone.

steps.title: Tap SD card and create the album.
steps.content: Tap SD card and create the album. Once you switch the album to the SD card, give it a name, and then tap Create .

steps.title: Return to your pictures and select the image(s) to move to the album.
steps.content: Return to your pictures and select the image(s) to move to the album. Tap and hold on an image until a checkmark appears in the top left corner of the thumbnail. Tap to select other photos.

steps.title: Tap ⋮.
steps.content: Tap ⋮ . You'll see this three-line menu option in the lower right corner of your screen.

steps.title: Tap Move to album.
steps.content: Tap Move to album . It's usually the third option down from the top of the menu.

steps.title: Tap the album you just created.
steps.content: Tap the album you just created. It's saved on the SD card, so moving the pictures will remove them from internal storage and only keep them on your SD card. If you chose Copy to album , the pictures will be available both on your SD card and internal storage. [6] X Research source
